Award.AwardTitle: Creating Synergy in Science and Education/Yuowanca

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
Creating Synergy in Science and Education (CSSE) will build on previous phases of TCUP Magakata Woslolye Oaye (Cultivating Science into the Future), which built an infrastructure of intellectual merit, faculty resources, facilities, scientific equipment and connections to the tribes and communities. Our vision continues to be to develop a model to strengthen science leadership at Tribal Colleges. The Cultivating Synergy in Science and Education program would expand on prior TCUP initiatives by cultivating scientific curiosity through collaborative undergraduate research and educational initiatives between mainstream Universities, Tribal Agencies and the K12 classroom. The project goals are as follows:
Goal 1: Improve the quality of undergraduate STEM education through developing OLC faculty and educational resources with the purpose of delivering hands-on, place-based STEM instruction for undergraduate students
Goal 2: Strengthen partnerships in within OLC, Tribal resource programs, and outside academic institutions
Goal 3: Broaden the pipeline of future STEM undergraduates at OLC

ProgramReference.Text: EXP PROG TO STIM COMP RES

POR.DRECONTENT:
Yuowanca Project Outcomes Report

Yuowanca (You' oh wahn chah), which is named for the Lakota word for the place where the tipi poles come together at the top, synergized K-12 students, faculty, staff, communities and tribe through relevant and research-based science and education.  Yuowanca built STEM departmental capacity in earth science, ecosystem science, chemistry, and biological sciences through providing academic development opportunities for Tribal College faculty and teaching staff, and developing a data infrastructure to archive and disseminate research results from reservation-based research to students, faculty, tribal programs, and other collaborators.  Furthermore, Yuowanca served the Native American population, which is severely underrepresented in STEM areas, through providing inquiry-based learning through K-12 outreach, academic enrichment, and undergraduate research opportunities for OLC students. 

The specific aims of Yuowanca were to: 1) strengthen educational and research relationships between a Tribal College, tribal resource programs, and mainstream universities to significantly increase the number of undergraduate students participating in research and service-learning, 2) provide informal science outreach to community members and K-12 schools, 3) develop principal investigators at Tribal Colleges, 4) integrate classroom learning and research experiences, and 5) address professional development needs at OLC through establishing more MS and PhD level faculty, teaching staff, and resource professionals at tribal agencies.

The specific outcomes of Yuowanca are: 1) OLC became the official Oglala Sioux Tribal Repository with collections and laboratories spaces including:  necropsy, microbiological, earth science and instrument laboratories, and curatorial facilities, and developed GIS and scientific collections in biology (bobcats, parasites, small mammals, aquatic macroinvertebrates, plants), geology (unpublished geological and soils maps), paleontology (Miocene and Eocene-age fossils), and archeology (cultural artifacts) cataloged in an NPS compliant database (Proficio), developed the OST Watershed Protection Plan, and Box Turtle species assessment for South Dakota; 2) grew student and faculty involvement in Tribal natural resource management, trained K-12 teachers in all Reservation schools and sustained a 500+ participant Science Fair; 3) developed two new faculty PIs with foci on biology, and sustainability engineering; 4) developed a co-curricular framework for undergraduate research in biology, geology, water resources management, and sustainability; and graduated Yuowanca participants with a majority entering the STEM workforce, and other participants defending Thesis and Dissertation proposals in Spring 2018.


Last Modified: 01/30/2018
Modified by: Charles J Tinant
